stimulusHtml: In a second experimental trial, the wheel is initially rotating counterclockwise. A piece of clay that has the same mass as the wheel is traveling directly to the right at a speed of 12m/s, colliding with, and sticking to, the top of the outer rim of the wheel. Which of the following claims about the motion of the clay-wheel system is correct, and has correct reasoning to support that claim?

features.html: A wheel is free to rotate with negligible friction about a fixed axle at its center. In separate experimental trials, different pieces of clay are launched toward the wheel’s rim, and each piece of clay collides with and sticks to the outer rim of the wheel, as shown in the figure. The wheel has a mass mW=0.080kg, a radius rW=0.40m, and rotational inertia about its center IW=mWrW2. Clay pieces of different mass are used in two different experimental trials.

choicesHtml: The system is not rotating after the collision because the clay and wheel have the same mass.
The system is not rotating after the collision because the initial angular momenta of the clay and wheel are in opposite directions.
The rotation of the system after the collision cannot be determined because the initial angular velocity of the wheel is unknown.
The rotation of the system after the collision cannot be determined because translational motion and rotational motion are independent motions.
